titleStmt.title: Ciuitatis amor. = The cities loue An entertainment by water, at Chelsey, and White-hall. At the ioyfull receiuing of that illustrious hope of Great Britaine, the high and mighty Charles, to bee created Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornewall, Earle of Chester, &c. Together with the ample order and solemnity of his Highnesse creation, as it was celebrated in his Maiesties palace of White-hall on Monday, the fourth of Nouember. 1616. As also the ceremonies of that ancient and honourable Order of the Knights of the Bath; and all the triumphs showne in honour of his royall creation.
titleStmt.author: Middleton, Thomas, d. 1627.

titleStmt.title: Ciuitatis amor. = The cities loue An entertainment by water, at Chelsey, and White-hall. At the ioyfull receiuing of that illustrious hope of Great Britaine, the high and mighty Charles, to bee created Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornewall, Earle of Chester, &c. Together with the ample order and solemnity of his Highnesse creation, as it was celebrated in his Maiesties palace of White-hall on Monday, the fourth of Nouember. 1616. As also the ceremonies of that ancient and honourable Order of the Knights of the Bath; and all the triumphs showne in honour of his royall creation.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.p: THE HIGHE & MIGHTIE PR. CHARLES PR. OF WALES D. OF CORN: YOR: ALB: & ROTHS: MARQ. OF ORM:&c

div.p: CIVITATIS AMOR. The Cities Loue.
An entertainement by water, at Chel≈øey, and White-hall.
At the ioyfull receiuing of that Illu≈øtrious Hope of Great Britaine, the High and Mighty CHARLES, To bee created Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornewall, Earle of Che≈øter, &c.
Together with the Ample Order and Solemnity of his Highne≈ø≈øe creation, as it was celebrated in his Maie≈øties Palace of White-hall on Monday, the fourth of Nouember. 1616.
As al≈øo the Ceremonies of that Ancient and Honourable Order of the Knights of the Bath; And all the Triumphs ≈øhowne in honour of his Royall Creation.
LONDON, Printed by Nicholas Okes for Thomas Archer, and are to be ≈øold at his ≈øhop in Popes-head-Pallace. 1616.

div.head: The Ample Order and Solemnity of Prince CHARLES his Creation
div.p:
HIS Maie≈øtie, as well to ≈øhew the bountie of his affection towards his Royall Sonne, as to ≈øettle in the hearts of his louing ≈øubiects, a liuely impre≈ø≈øion of his Kingly care, for continuance of the happy and peaceable gouernement of his Land in his i≈ø≈øue and po≈øteritie, hauing determined to inue≈øt his Princely Highne≈ø≈øe, with tho≈øe Titles and Solemnities which the former Princes of his Realme haue v≈øually beene adorned; it ≈øeemed fitte≈øt, both in regard of his Highne≈ø≈øe yeares, ≈øhewing the rare proofes of promi≈øing heroicall vertues, and al≈øo that it would bee a gladne≈ø≈øe mo≈øt gratefull and acceptable to the Common-wealth, to haue the
Solemnities thereof royally performed: To the effecting of which the L. Maior and Aldermen of the Citie of London, with the ≈øeuerall Companies, Honourably furni≈øhed and appointed, and Mar≈øh'alld in faire and comely order, (both by the care and indu≈øtry of Mr. Nicholas Leate, Citizen and Marchant of London, and one of the chiefe Captaines for the Citie; as al≈øo by the well ob≈øerued and de≈øeruing paines of Mai≈øter Thomas Sparro, Water-Bayly, made for that day Mar≈øhall for the water Triumphs) were ready attending, with a great Traine, and co≈øtly entertainement, to receiue his Highne≈ø≈øe at Chel≈øie, their Barges richly deckt with Banners, Streamers, and En≈øignes, and ≈øundry ≈øorts of lowd ≈øounding in≈øtruments aptly placed among≈øt them; And for his Graces fir≈øt entertainment, which was neere Chel≈øie, A Per≈øonage figuring London ≈øitting vpon a Sea-Vnicorne, with ≈øixe Tritons ≈øounding before her, accompanied both with Neptune and the two Riuers Thame≈øis and Dee, at his fir≈øt appearing, ≈øpeakes as followeth.

div.head: The Citties Loue The Entertainment by Water at Chel≈øey and White-hall.
div.stage: A Per≈øonage figuring London, ≈øitting vpon a Sea-Vnicorne, with ≈øixe Tritons ≈øounding before her, accompanyed thither with Neptune, and the two Riuers Thame≈øis and Dee.
At the fir≈øt appearing of the Prince, ≈øpeakes as followeth:

sp.speaker: London
sp.l: NEptune! ≈øince thou ha≈øt beene at all this paines,
Not onely with thy Tritons to ≈øupply mee,
But art thy ≈øelfe come from thy vtmo≈øt Maines,
To fea≈øt vpon that Ioy that's now ≈øo nigh mee,
To make our Loues the better vnder≈øtood,
Silence thy Watry Subiect, this ≈ømall Floud.

div.stage: Neptune giues action toward Thame≈øis, and ≈øpeakes,

sp.l: BY the timely Ebbes and Flowes,
That make thee famous to all tho≈øe
That mu≈øt ob≈øerue thy pretious Tides
That i≈ø≈øue from our wealthy ≈øides:
Not a murmure, not a ≈øound,
That may this Ladies Voyce confound,
And Tritons, who by our commanding power
Attend vpon the Glory of this Hower,
To do it ≈øeruice, and the Citie Grace,
Be ≈øilent, till wee waue our ≈øiluer Mace.

sp.speaker: London.
sp.l: ANd you our honour'd Sonnes, who≈øe Loyalty,
Seruice, and zeale, ≈øhall bee expre≈øt of mee,
Let not your louing ouer-greedy Noy≈øe,
Beguile you of the Sweetne≈ø≈øe of your Ioyes.
My wi≈øh ha's tooke effect, for ne'r was knowne
A greater Ioy, and a more ≈øilent one.

div.stage: Then turning to the Prince, thus ≈øpeakes.

sp.l: TRea≈øure of hope, and Iewell of mankind,
Richer, no Kingdomes peace did euer ≈øee;
Adorn'd in Titles, but much more in minde,
The loues of many thou≈øands ≈øpeake in mee:
Who, from that ble≈øsing of our peacefull ≈øtore
Thy Royall Father, ha≈øt receiu'd mo≈øt free,
Honours that wooed thy Vertues long before,
And e're thy Time were capable of thee:
Thou, who≈øe mo≈øt earely goodne≈ø≈øe fixt in youth
Do's promi≈øe comfort to the length of Time,
As wee on earth mea≈øure heauens workes by truth,
And things which Naturall rea≈øon cannot clime:
So, when wee looke into the Vertuous Aime
Of thy Diuine Addiction, wee may deeme
By Rules of Grace, and Principles of Fame,
What worth will bee, now in ≈øo high e≈øteeme,
And ≈øo betimes pur≈øued; which thought vpon,
Neuer more cau≈øe this Land had to reioyce,
But chiefly I, the Citie, that has knowen
More of this good then any, and more choi≈øe:
What a Faire Glorious Peace for many yeares,
Has ≈øung her ≈øweete calmes to the hearts of men?
Enricht our homes, extingui≈øh't forraine feares,
And at this houre beginnes her Hymnes agen:
Liue long, and happy, Glory of our daies,
And thy ≈øweete Time markt with all faire pre≈øages,
Since heauen is plea≈øde in thy ble≈øt life to rai≈øe,
The Hope of the≈øe, and Ioy of after Ages.
Sound Tritons, lift our loues vp with his Fame,
Proclaim'd as far as Honour ha's a Name.

div.p: Neptune‚ÄîSound‚ÄîOn‚Äî

div.head: The Entertainement at White-hall.
div.stage: This Per≈øonage, figuring London (with the ≈øixe Tritons ≈øounding before, Neptume, and the two Riuers) being arriu'd at White-hall, where attend the Princes Landing, the Figures of two ≈øacred Deities, Hope and Peace thus ≈øpeaks.

sp.speaker: London.
sp.l: HOpe! now behold the Fulne≈ø≈øe of thy Good,
Which thy ≈øicke comforts haue expected long,
And thou ≈øweete Peace the Harmony of this floud,
Looke vp, and ≈øee the Glory of thy Song.

div.stage: Hope leaning her Brea≈øt vpon a ≈øiluer Anchor, attended with foure Virgins all in white, hauing ≈øiluer Oares in their hands, thus An≈øweres.

sp.speaker: Hope.
sp.l: FAire and mo≈øt Famous Citie, thou ha≈øt wak't me,
From the ≈øad ≈ølumber of di≈øcon≈øolate Feare,
Which at the Mu≈øick of thy Voyce for≈øak't me,
And now begin to ≈øee my Comforts cleare,
Now ha's my Anchor her firme hold agen,
And in my ble≈øt and calme Securitie,
The expectations of all faithfull men,
Haue their full fruites being ≈øatisfyed in mee.
This is the place that I'le ca≈øt Anchor in,
This, Honours Hauen, the Kings Royall Court,
Heere will I fa≈øten all my ioyes agen,
Where all de≈øeruers and de≈øerts re≈øort:
And may I neuer change this happy ≈øhoare,
Till all be chang'd neuer to alter more.

div.stage: Then Peace ≈øitting on a Dolphin, with her ≈øacred Quire, ≈øings this ≈øong following.

lg.head: The Song of Peace.
lg.l: VVElcome, oh welcome Spring of Ioy & Peace,
Borne to be honour'd, and to giue encrea≈øe
To tho≈øe that waite vpon thy Graces,
'Mong≈øt which The Cities Loue is fir≈øt,
But ≈øuch a Prince, and ≈øuch a day.
Welcome, oh welcome, all Faire Ioyes attend thee,
Glorie of life, to ≈øafety we commend thee.

div.head: Prince Charles his Creation.
div.p: THe dayes Triumph ended, to the great Honour of the City, and content of his Highne≈ø≈øe, who out of the goodne≈ø≈øe of his loue, gaue the Lord Maior and Aldermen many thankes.
On Monday following, the Lords and Peeres of the Realme being all a≈ø≈øembled at White-hall, his Highne≈ø≈øe then proceeded in this maner to his Creation.

Fir≈øt went the Trumpets, then the Heralds and Officers of Armes in their rich Coates; next followed the Knights of the Bath, beeing ≈øixe and twentie in number, apparelled in long robes of purple Sattin, lined with white Taffata; then ≈øir William Segar Knight, ali√¢s Garter, principall King of Armes, bearing the Letters Patents, the Earle of Su≈ø≈øex the Purple Robes, the Traine borne by the Earle of Huntington, the Sword by the Earle of Rutland, the Ring by the Earle of Derby, the Rodde by the Earle of Shrewe≈øbury, the Cappe and Coronet by the Duke of
Lenox, Lord Steward, his Princely Highne≈ø≈øe ≈øupported by the Earles of Suffolke and Nottingham, came bare-headed, and ≈øo entred the great Hall, where the King was ≈øet in his royall Throane, and the whole State of the Realme in their Order; the Prince made lowe obei≈øance to his Maie≈øtie three times, and after the third time, when hee was come neere to the King, hee kneeled downe on a rich Pillow or Cu≈øhion, while≈øt ≈øir Ralph Winwood principall Secretarie, read his Letters Patents: then his Maie≈øtie, at the reading of the words of Inue≈øtment, put the Robes vpon him, and girded on the Sword, inue≈øted him with the Rodde and Ring, and ≈øet the Cappe and Coronet on his head. With which Ceremonie the Creation being accompli≈øhed, the King aro≈øe, and went vp to Dinner; but the Prince, with his Lords, dined in the Hall, and was ≈øerued with great State and Magnificence, accompanied at his Table with diuers great Lords, as the Earle of Suffolke Lord Trea≈øurer, the Earle of Arundell Lord Mar≈øhall, the Earle of Nottingham Lord Admirall, the Duke of Lenox Lord Steward, the Earle of Penbrooke Lord Chamberlaine, the Erles of Shrew≈øbury, Darby, Rutland, and Su≈ø≈øex, the Prince ≈øitting in a Chaire at the vpper end, and the re≈øt in di≈øtance about foure yards from him, one oueragain≈øt another, in their degrees, all which were tho≈øe that were employed in ≈øeuerall Offices of Honour about his Royall Creation.

At another Table in the ≈øame Rowme on the left hand of the Prince, ≈øate the Knights of the Bath, all on one ≈øide, and had likewi≈øe great ≈øeruice and attendance. About the midde≈øt of Dinner, ≈øir William Segar Knight, ali√¢s Garter, principall King of Armes, with the re≈øt of the Kings Heralds and Pur≈øuvants of Armes, approached the Princes Table, and with a lowde and audible voyce, proclaimed the Kings Stile, in Latine, French and Engli≈øh thriee; and the Princes in like manner, twice: then the Trumpets ≈øounding, the ≈øecond Cour≈øe came in; and Dinner done, that dayes Solemnitie cea≈øed.

At night, to crowne it with more heroicall honour, fortie worthie Gentlemen of the Noble Societies of Innes of Court, being tenne of each hou≈øe, euery one appoynted in way of honorable Combate, to breake three Staues, three Swords, and exchange ten blowes apeece, who≈øe names (for their worthine≈ø≈øe) I commend to Fame, beganne thus each to encounter other. And not to wrong the ≈øacred Antiquitie of anie of the Hou≈øes, their names are heere ≈øet downe in the ≈øame order as they were pre≈øented to his Maie≈øtie; viz. Of the

list.item: Middle Temple, Mai≈øter Strowd. Mai≈øter Izord.
Grayes Inne, Mai≈øter Courthop. Mai≈øter Calton.
Lincolnes Inne, Ma≈øter Skinner. Ma≈øter Windham
Inner Temple, Ma≈øter Crow. Ma≈øter Vernon.
Middle Temple, Ma≈øter Argent. Ma≈øt. Gla≈øcocke.
Grayes Inne, Mai≈øter Wadding. Mai≈øter St-Iohn.
Lincolnes Inne, Ma≈øter Griffin. Ma≈øter Fletcher.
Inner Temple, Mai≈øter Par≈øons. Mai≈øter Brocke.
Middle Temple, M. Bentley ≈øenior. Mai≈øter Peere.
Grayes Inne, Mai≈øter Selwyn. Mai≈øter Pa≈øton.
Lincolnes Inne, Mae≈øter Selwyn. Ma≈øter Clinch.
Inner Temple, Ma≈øter Chetwood. M. Smalman.
Middle Temple, Ma. Bentley iunior. Ma. Bridges.
Grayes Inne, Mai≈øter Couert. Mai≈øter Fulkes.
Lincolnes Inne, Mai≈øter Iones. Mai≈øter Googe.
Inner Temple, Mai≈øter Wilde. Mai≈øter Chaue.
Middle Temple, Ma≈øter Wan≈øted. Ma. Goodyeere.
Grayes Inne, Mai≈øter Burton. Mai≈øter Bennet.
Lincolnes Inne, Ma≈øter Hitchcocke. Ma. Neuill.
Inner Temple, Ma≈øter Littleton. Ma≈øter Treuer.

div.p: On Wedne≈øday the ≈øixt day of Nouember, to giue greater lu≈øtre and honour to this Triumph and Solemnitie, in the pre≈øence of the King, Queene, Prince, and Lords, foureteene right Honorable and Noble per≈øonages, who≈øe names heereafter follow, graced this dayes Magnificence, with Running at the Ring; viz.

list.item: The Duke of Lenox Lord Steward.
Earle of Penbroke L. Chamberlaine.
Earle of Rutland.
Earle of Dor≈øet.
Earle of Montgomery.
Vicount Villiers.
Lord Clifford.
Lord Walden.
Lord Mordant.
Sir Thomas Howard.
Sir Robert Rich.
Sir Gilbert Gerrard.
Sir William Cauendi≈øh.
Sir Henry Rich.

div.p: Hauing thus briefly de≈øcribed the manner of his Highne≈ø≈øe Creation, with the honourable Seruice ≈øhewne to the Solemnitie, both by the Lords and Gentlemen of the Innes of Court, I ≈øhould haue ≈øet a Period, but that the Knights of the Bath, being a principall part and ornament of this ≈øacred Triumph, I can not pa≈ø≈øe them ouer without ≈øome remembrance: therefore thus much out of the Note of Directions, from ≈øome of the principall Officers of Armos, and ≈øome ob≈øeruation of credite, concerning the Order and Ceremonies of the Knighthood.

The Lords and other that were to receiue the Honourable Order of the Bath, repayred on Satterday the ≈øecond of Nouember to the Parliament hou≈øe at We≈øtmin≈øter, and there in the afternoone heard Euening Prayer, ob≈øeruing no other Ceremonie at that time, but onely the Heralds going before them in their ordinarie habites from thence to King Henrie the ≈øeauenths Chappell at We≈øtmin≈øter, there to beginne their warrefare, as if they would employ their ≈øeruice for God e≈øpecially; from whence, after
Seruice ended, they returned into the Chamber they were to ≈øuppe in: their ≈øupper was prepared all at one Table, and all ≈øate vpon one ≈øide of the ≈øame, euery maÃÑ hauing an E≈øcutcheon of his Armes placed ouer his head, and certaine of the Kings Officers being appoynted to attend them. In this manner hauing taken their repa≈øt, ≈øeuerall beds were made ready for their lodging in another rowme hard by, after the ≈øame manner, all on one ≈øide; their beddes were Pallats, with Couerings, Te≈øters, or Canopies of Red Say, but they v≈øed no Curtaines.

The Knights in the meane while were withdrawne into the Bathing Chamber, which was the next rowme to that which they ≈øupped in; where, for each of them was prouided a ≈øeuerall bathing Tubbe, which was lined both within and without, with white Linnen, and couered with Red Say: wherein, after they haue ≈øaid their prayers, and commended them≈øelues to God, they bathe them≈øelues, that thereby they might be put in minde, to be pure in bodie and ≈øoule from thenceforth; and after the Bath, they betooke them≈øelues to their re≈øt.

Earely the next morning they were awakened with Mu≈øicke, and at their vpri≈øing, inue≈øted in their Hermites habites, which was a Gowne of Gray Cloth girded clo≈øe, and a Hoode of the ≈øame, and a linnen Coife vnderneath, and an Hankercher hanging at his girdle, cloth Stockings ≈øoaled with Leather, but no Shooes; and
thus apparelled, their E≈øquiers Gouernors, with the Heralds wearing the Coates of Armes, and ≈øundry ≈øorts of winde-In≈øtruments before them, they proceede from their lodging, the meane≈øt in order formo≈øt, as the nighr before, vntill they came to the Chappell, where after Seruice ended, their Oath was mini≈øtred vnto them by the Earle of Arundell Lord Mar≈øhall, and the Earle of Penbroke Lord Chamberlaine, in a ≈øolemne and ceremonious manner, all of them ≈øtanding foorth before their ≈øtalles, and at their coming out making low reuerence towards the Altar, by which the Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øate, then were they brought vp by the Heralds by two at once, the chiefe≈øt fir≈øt, and ≈øo the re≈øt, till all ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely had receiued their Oath, which in effect was this; That aboue all things they ≈øhould ≈øeek the honour of God, and maintenance of true Religion, loue their Soueraigne, ≈øerue their Countrie, helpe Maydens, Widdowes, and Orphans, and (to the vtmo≈øt of their power) cau≈øe Equity and Iu≈øtice to be ob≈øerued.

This day, while≈øt they were yet in the Chappell, wine and ≈øweet meates were brought them, and they departed to their Chamber to be di≈ørobed of their Hermites weedes, and were reue≈øted in Roabes of Crim≈øon Taffata, implying they ≈øhould be Martiall men, the Robes lined with white Sarcenet, in token of Sincerity, hauing white Hattes on their heads, with white Feathers, white Bootes on their legges, and
white Gloues tied vnto the ≈øtrings of their Mantles: all which performed, they mount on hor≈øebacke, the Saddle of blacke leather, the Ar≈øon white, Stirrop leathers blacke, gilt, the pectorall of blacke leather, with a cro≈ø≈øe Paty of Siluer thereon, and without a Crupper, the Bridle likewi≈øe blacke, with a cro≈ø≈øe Paty on the Forehead or Frontlet: each Knight betweene his two E≈øquiers well apparrelled, his Footeman attending, and his Page riding before him, carrying his Sword with the hiltes vpward, in a white leather Belt without Buckles or Studdes, and his Spurres hanging thereon.

In this order ranked, euery man according to his degree, the be≈øt or chiefe≈øt fir≈øt, they rode faire and ≈øoftly towards the Court, the Trumpets ≈øounding, and the Heralds all the way riding before them being come to the Kings hall, the Mar≈øhall meetes them, who is to haue their hor≈øes, or el≈øe 100. s. in money for his Fee: then conducted by the Heralds, and others appoynted for that purpo≈øe, his Maie≈øtie ≈øitting vnder his Cloth of E≈øtate, gaue to them their Knighthood in this manner:

Fir≈øt, the principall Lord that is to receiue the Order, comes, led by his two E≈øquiers, and his Page before him, bearing his Sword and Spurs, and kneeleth downe before his Maie≈øtie, the Lord Chamberlain takes the Sword of the page, and deliuers it to the King, who puts the Belt ouer the necke of the Knight, a≈ølope his brea≈øt,
placing the Sword vnder his left Arme: the ≈øecond Nobleman of the chiefe about the King, puts on his Spurres, the right Spurre fir≈øt; and ≈øo is the ceremony performed. In this ≈øort Lord Maltreuers ≈øonne and heire to the Erle of Arundell, Lord Mar≈øhall, which was the principall of this number, being fir≈øt created, the re≈øt were all con≈øequently knighted alike: And when the ≈øolemnitie thereof was fully fini≈øhed, they all returned in order as they came, ≈øauing ≈øome ≈ømall difference, in that the yonge≈øt or meane≈øt knight went now formo≈øt, & their Pages behinde them.

Coming backe to the Parliament hou≈øe, their dinner was ready prepared in the ≈øame rowme, and after the fa≈øhion as their ≈øupper was the night before; but being ≈øet, they were notto ta≈øte of any thing that ≈øtood before them, but with a mode≈øt carriage, and gracefull ab≈øtinence, to refraine: diuers kindes of ≈øweet Mu≈øicke ≈øounding the while; and after a conuenient time of ≈øitting, to ari≈øe, and withdraw them≈øelues, leauing the Table ≈øo furni≈øhed to their E≈øquiers and Pages.

About fiue of the clocke in the afternoone, they rode againe to Court, to heare Seruice in the Kings Chappell, keeping the ≈øame order they did at their returne from thence in the morning, euery Knight riding betweene his two E≈øquiers, and his Page following him.

At their entrance into the Chappell, the Heralds conducting them, they make a ≈øolemne reuerence,
the yonge≈øt Knight beginning, the re≈øt orderly en≈øuing, and ≈øo one after another take their ≈øtanding before their Stalls, where all being placed, the elde≈øt Knight maketh a ≈øecond Reuerence, which is followed to the yonge≈øt, and then all a≈øcend into their Stalls, and take their accu≈øtomed places.

Seruice then beginneth, and is very ≈øolemnly celebrated with ≈øinging of diuers Anthemes to the Organs, And when the Time of their Offertorie is come, the yonge≈øt Knights are ≈øummoned forth of their Stalls by the Heralds, doing reuerence fir≈øt within their Stalls, and againe after they are di≈øcended, which is likewi≈øe imitated by all the re≈øt; and being all thus come forth, ≈øtanding before their Stalls as at fir≈øt, the two elde≈øt Knights with their ≈øwords in their hands, are brought vp by the Heralds to the Altar, where they offer their ≈øwords, and the Deane receiues them, of whom they pre≈øently redeeme them with an Angell in Gold, and then come downe to their former places, whil≈øt two other are led vp in like manner: The ceremonie performed, and ≈øeruice ended, they depart againe in ≈øuch order as they came, with accu≈øtomed Reuerence; At the Chappell doore as they came forth, they were encountred by the Kings Mai≈øter Cooke, who ≈øtood there with his white Apron & Sleeues, and a chopping knife in his hand, and challenged their Spurres, which were likewi≈øe redeemed with a Noble in money, threatning
them neuerthele≈ø≈øe, that if they proued not true and loyall to the King his Lord and Mai≈øter, it mu≈øt be his Office to hew them from their heeles. On Monday morning they all met together nigh at the Court, where in a priuate Roome appointed for them, they were cloathed in long Robes of Purple Sattin, with Hoods of the ≈øame, all lined and edged about with white Taffata: And thus appareled, they gaue their attendance vpon the Prince at his creation, & dined that day in his pre≈øence at a ≈øide Boord, as is already declared.

list.head: The Names of ≈øuch Lords, and Gentlemen, as were made Knights of the Bath, in honour of his Highne≈ø≈øe Creation.

L. Barkley.

Sir Henry Howard, 2 ≈øonne to the E. of Arundell.

Sir William Howard, 5. ≈øon to the Earle of Suffolke.
Sir Edward Howard, 6. ≈øon to the Earle of Suffolke.
Sir Montague Bartue, elde≈øt ≈øonne to the Lord Willoughby of Er≈øby.
Sir William Stourton, ≈øonne to the Lord Stourton.
Sir Henry Parker, ≈øonne to the Lord Mounteagle.
Sir Dudly North, elde≈øt ≈øonne to the Lord North.

Sir Rowland St. Iohn, 3. ≈øon to the Lord Saint Iohn.

div.p: And for an Honourable conclu≈øion of the Kings Royall Grace and bounty ≈øhewne to this Solemnitie, his Maie≈øty created Thomas Lord Ele≈ømere, Lord Chancelour of England, Vicount Brackley; The L. Knolles, Vicount Wallingford, Sir Phillip Stanhope, L. Stanhope of Shelford in Nottingham-≈øhire. The≈øe being created on Thur≈øday the ≈øeuenth of Nouember, the Lord Chancellour Vicount Brackley, being led out of the Councell Chamber into the Priuie Gallery, by the Earle of Montgomery and Vicount Villiers, the Vicount Wallingford, by the Earle of Suffolke Lord Trea≈øurer and the Vicount Li≈øle, the Lord Stanhope, by the Lord Danuers and the Lord Carew, &c.
